subject: Re: re - novice QA
msgSnippet: Shane, Well, I am writing a tool to test binary compatibility between versions.  Basically, I load each version up using my own class loader, and then compare
messageBody:
Shane,

Well, I am writing a tool to test binary compatibility between
versions. Basically, I load each version up using my own class
loader, and then compare them to eachother. However, the way that I
designed the program was that all the errors were stored, and then
just printed out by the user however he wanted. I wrote the code
myself (both the toolkit code and the junit code). I have tried
making my (BC) code more test worthy, as suggested earlier in this
forum, such as instead of printing the results, I have a getList
method so I can compare the list to a hardcoded list, however, this
does not seem to fit in with the mentality of unit test writing. Is
that a better picture of what I am trying to do? I have a unit test
running now, but I just feel that my design is very sloppy and
amateurish.

Thanks!

--- In junit@y..., Shane Duan <sduan@b...> wrote:
> If you can provide more information, I might have a better answer.
>
> What kind of 'certain type of compatibility' are you referring to?
>
> 'my code' mentioned in your earlier post is referring to your unit
testing code
> is that correct?
>
> As to your question of add, I suspect that what you have learned in
school is
> in procedure language instead of object oriented language. So if
you have two
> variable 'a' and 'b', in procedure language it is 'add(a, b)',
while in object
> oriented language it is 'a.add(b)'. In fact, I think in the early
days of C++
> the compile just convert a.add(b) to add(a, b).
>
> Hope that is clear.
>
>
> Jason Rogers wrote:
>
> > He said he was the author of the code, so I don't think that will
work.
